comment: Tasty. Nice Bottle and Label. Looks like it would have been distilled at the Old Seagrams Distillery in Lawrenveburg Ten Years ago. 2005 or 2006? LDI or MGPI wouldn't have made this one..Seagrams made it. The only thing better would be a Seagrams 95% Rye from 2005/2006

Just tried this new offering from Boone County KY Distillers and it's not a bad pour. Aged 10 Years, or so it says on the bottle, a bit of a bite at the start with a rather smooth finish. Has a little bit of a spicy flavor similar to Basil Hayden, just not as pronounced. I feel it is somewhat over priced as I paid just over $55 for 750ml. My understanding this offering came available December 2015.  I feel this is a $35-$40 Bourbon

Notes or baking spice and black pepper nose, with plenty of caramel and toasted vanilla

Sweet in the mouth, slight oily character too. Long finish, really good and complex...great by itself or in a whiskey forward cocktail
Single Barrel, 12 Years, Barrel Strength, 109.36 Proof, Barrel #B0506
Boone County Single Barrel 12 years, Eighteen 33. 109.44 proof Barrel Strength.
Great Whiskey, if you can find it.
A lot of up-front bite, then fades quickly with light finish. Very interesting drink.
solid flavor! fits my she and proof range well
12 Year - Auburn color with an oily mouthfeel. Caramel, oak, and maple on the nose. Caramel, red hot candy, alcohol, and oak on the palate.
Very nice and smooth. Little cinnamon and vanilla.
Corn not as sweet and the not as sharp as some with this mash bill
Could have earned 4 stars if it wasn’t quite so boring. It’s a good pour and I’ll enjoy the bottle but it seems a bit uninspired. It would probably be a solid 4 if not 4.5 if the proof was higher.

A nice dark-reddish copper color.
This one has a really nice nose. Dark fruit, wood spice and sweet corn dominate an intense aroma that has my expectations high.
The flavor profile is not as intense as the nose would suggest, but still quite nice. A soft mouthfeel is supported by vanilla, oak and the same sweet fruit profile I was nosing. 
This one is best without water as it dilutes an already-balanced, lower ABV (46%) bourbon. 3.95.
Spicy burn up front with a slight oaky vanilla kick. Toffee and caramel with a touch of cinnamon notes.
Yeasty, nutty, marzipan, caramel toffee, chocolate, orange zest, cinnamon
best bourbon I've had so far

This is a lesser known bourbon from Norther KY and it is a fantastic bourbon.  It is very smooth with a great nutty and yeasty finish.  It is easy on the nose and is best neat.  If you can find a bottle of the 12 or 13 year single barrel (99 and 143 bottles) you are in for a real treat

About $35 for the 375ml “Snyder’s Flask” 12 year at the gift shop of Boone County Distilling Co. 

Color: Dark Orange/Auburn

Nose: a truly wonderful bouquet- toffee and I think some slight chocolate, caramel and vanilla, honey, slight ethanol, some oak at the end 

Palate: tobacco and leather, toffee and caramel, ethanol, honey and vanilla on the finish (short) with a slight cinnamon linger

Boone County knew what they were doing when they picked this mash bill and these MGP barrels. Although I felt like the experience was a little short, there is a tiny remnant of sweet tobacco to remind to take another sip.

This was an impulse buy at my local Kroger and turned into one of my better decisions. 

I didn’t know anything about this bottle when I picked it up. The bottle itself is intriguing: the label is an eye-catching blue and orange with an old-time style script proclaiming its name and the year that William and John Snyder founded their distillery on the banks of the Ohio in northern Kentucky: Eighteen 33. There is a great story on the label about the hard work and sacrifice of those early distillers and it concludes with the phrase, “Made by Ghosts”. With all that I’d probably like it even if the whiskey was mediocre. Fortunately, it’s much better than that. 

Boone County Eighteen 33 straight bourbon whiskey is a ten year old distillate produced by MGP. There is a great story out there from the founders of this distillery about how they came across these 1000 barrels of whiskey that they purchased to sell while their distillery gets up and running but I’ll be damned if I can find it now to provide the link. Oh well, on to the tasting.

This whiskey is derived from a mash bill of 75% corn, 21% rye, and 4% malted barley. It’s bottled at a respectable 45.4% ABV. It’s a gorgeous dark amber in the glass and forms long, slow developing legs when given a spin. 

The nose is a beautiful sweet bomb of buttery caramel, brown sugar, a hint of vanilla, and light cinnamon. It’s a Cinnabon sweet roll in a glass. In the mouth it’s more of the same: butterscotch and warm baking spices with hints of tobacco and leather. Considering it’s 10 year age, there is very little oak; just that amazing sweet roll. If sweet whiskey is not your thing you might want to think twice about this dram. But the rest of us will just keep enjoying. 

The rye kicks in in the finish with cinnamon and pepper. It’s nice and warm and leaves you wanting more. This was $65 locally. At that price it’s definitely at the top of my bourbon price range. But I have to say I’m not disappointed. This is one of the better bourbons I’ve had lately and I’m glad took a chance on it. I will probably replace it when it’s gone, it’s that good. 4/5 even considering the price. Cheers!
This is good. Very complex. Thick mouth feel. Get nice oak but not astringent. Medium finish. Butterscotch with spice.
Definitely can taste the high corn mash bill (74%). Smooth and fairly easy to drink. Typical high corn whiskey.
Underrated. Very nice taste at a reasonable price.
Nose is super sweet, honey like...burns and numbs the palate on the first 3-4 sips...becomes smooth on the way down in the finish! Great sipper!!!
Floral on the nose, corn centric.  Oaky on the palate, charcoal heavy.  A lingering but short alcoholic finish.
a little hot on the front end. quickly diminishs for a very smooth slightly sweet finish. love it.

12 year store pick, Prav Saraff, 113.52 proof. What a great nose. Sweet caramel, oak. That carries over to the palate, with a nice earthy note mixed in. Slight acidic kick, with baking spice. Doughy. This is delicious. 8/24/18

12 year store pick, Modern Liquors, 114.40 proof. Muted nose initially, but what's there is good. After a while it opens up with caramel, maybe a hint of sour fruit. On the palate, tastes like cola. Warmth lingers in the chest. 8/24/18

12 year store pick, Gordon's, 121.88 proof. Smells sweet and oaky. Some fresh linen. On the plate, a flash of spice. Sweet oak throughout. Warm. 8/24/18

This is a darn fine sip.  Light nondescript sweet aromas lead to a surprisingly Full mouth feel, almost heavy.  Buttery smooth, with almost no burn at all.  Rich with caramel, honey, vanilla and a small hit of spice on the finish. Absolutely would buy this again.
Great Find at local store.  It was $21 and I’m headed back there tomorrow to pickup another 2 bottles.
